columns: In 2013: only 55% of the city had a local health clinic; 74% of women received medical care; and the average life expectancy was 63.
In 2013, the infant mortality rate was 19% of children dying before the age of 5.
In Favelas, 12% of homes have no running water, 50% have no sewage connection and 30% have no electricity access.
Only half of children continue their education past the age of 14.
There is no waste collection in the Favelas, so rubbish piles up in the streets, causing disease.
Poorly constructed housing.
Robbery and violent crime present great challenges for Rio. Murder kidnapping, carjacking and armed assault occur regularly.
The murder rate is 20 out of 1000 people
In Santa Marta, a Favela in Rio, medical staff took a health kit into people's homes and were able to detect 20 different diseases and treat them. This improved infant mortality and life expectancy.
7 new water treatment plants and over 300km of pipes were laid between 1998 and 2024, increasing the water supply rate to 95%.
60km of new power lines, a nuclear power plant and a new hydro-electric complex has increased Rio's electricity suppl by 30%
In 2013 Pacifying Police Units (UPPs) were established to reclaim Favelas from drug dealers.
Hit by a deep recession in 2015.
About 1/3 of Rio's 3.5 million workers don't have a formal employment contract, and many are without insurance.
Unemployment rates in the Favelas are over 20%
The local government is using education to try to reduce youth unemployment.
The government are trying to improve education for young people in poor and violent areas

> 50 tonnes of industrial waste enters the bay each day

Ships empty their fuel tanks into the bay because there are no fuel disposal facilities
5000 deaths per year are caused by air pollution in Rio
Lots of congestion due to poor road infrastructure
The number of cars has grown by 40% over the pas decade
High crime means people prefer to travel by car

Expansion of the metro system

Making busy coastal roads one way during peak hours

content.data: The Favela Bairro Project (favela neighbourhood project) began in 1994 and ended in 2008

The aim was to provide essential services to residents and to recognise them formally as neighbourhoods of the city
Families were taught to build stable foundations using strong materials
Residents living in homes deemed too unsafe on the steep hillside were relocated by the local government
Solid, brick homes were built with power, running clean water and sanitation pipes, reducing the impact of waterborne diseases such as cholera
Some residents were able to purchase the homes and were given legal rights to the land
Cultural activities such as samba, capoeira and reggae are run to stop youths from getting involved in gangs and organised crime
The success of these schemes has been mixed, but many living conditions have been improved, but the topography of the area (steep hillsides) has restricted full development
Improvements are restricted by steep hillsides, heavy rains, floods and landslides
Funding is limited, making improvement for all residents impossible
